detail.title: Optimal Cruise Speeds and Environmental Impacts on Energy use of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles for Last-Mile Delivery
detail.abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly recognised as a viable option for urban parcel delivery. However, their energy performance under varying environmental and mission conditions remains underexplored. This study presents a simulation-based analysis of multirotor UAV energy consumption using the PX4-Gazebo platform, calibrated with real-world flight data. Three UAV models-Iris, Typhoon H480 and Octocopter-were evaluated across a range of payloads (0.1-5 kg), cruise speeds (2-16 m/s) and environmental factors, including wind, temperature and humidity. Results revealed consistent U-shaped energy-speed curves, with optimal cruise speeds ranging from 8 to 10 m/s, depending on the payload and platform. Environmental factors such as headwinds and low temperatures increased energy consumption by up to 25%. Validation against field telemetry showed mean absolute percentage errors below 11%. These findings offer a robust framework for UAV mission planning, platform selection and integration into low-emission logistics networks.

AI.method: 使用PX4-Gazebo平台进行仿真分析，并用真实飞行数据校准，评估三种无人机模型（Iris、Typhoon H480和Octocopter）在不同载荷（0.1-5kg）、巡航速度（2-16m/s）和环境因素（风、温度、湿度）下的能耗。

title: Passive Investors and Loan Spreads
affiliations: University of St. Gallen - School of Finance, Bank for International Settlements and Bank for International Settlements (BIS) - Monetary and Economic Department

detail.title: Passive Investors and Loan Spreads
detail.abstract: Over the past decades, index funds have amassed substantial ownership stakes in publicly traded firms, which raises questions about their influence on governance and monitoring. This paper examines how banks adjust their loan pricing when firms have a higher share of passive index fund investors as shareholders. Using syndicated loan data, we find that loan spreads increase with passive ownership, and provide evidence consistent with higher loan spreads reflecting increased risk due to reduced shareholder oversight. Supporting this interpretation, we find stronger effects among well-governed and informationally opaque firms, where shareholder oversight is more impactful. However, the increase in loan spreads is not fully accounted for by changes in traditional measures of firm risk. Suggestive evidence points towards banks increasing their monitoring intensity in response to changes in shareholder composition, which is costly and reflected in loan spreads.

AI.tldr: 研究发现被动指数基金持股比例增加会导致银行贷款利差上升，这反映了由于股东监督减少而增加的信贷风险，银行会加强监控来应对这种风险变化。
AI.research_question: 当企业被动指数基金投资者持股比例较高时，银行如何调整贷款定价？
AI.motivation: 过去几十年指数基金在上市公司中积累了大量股权，这引发了对其在公司治理和监督方面影响的疑问。
AI.theoretical_framework: 基于公司治理理论和信贷风险定价理论，探讨被动投资者对股东监督机制的影响。
AI.method: 使用银团贷款数据，分析被动所有权与贷款利差之间的关系。
AI.findings: 贷款利差随被动所有权增加而上升，这种效应在治理良好和信息不透明的公司中更强，表明利差上升反映了因股东监督减少而增加的风险。
AI.theory_contributions: 深化了对被动投资者在公司治理中作用的理解，揭示了股东结构变化对信贷风险定价的影响机制。

title: Oil Price Shocks and Cash Flow Timing Patterns: Evidence from Corporate Year-End Cash Collection
affiliations: Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT University) - School of Economics, Finance and Marketing, Swinburne University of Technology, Swinburne University of Technology - Department of Accounting, Economics, and Finance and Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT University) - School of Economics, Finance and Marketing

detail.title: Oil Price Shocks and Cash Flow Timing Patterns: Evidence from Corporate Year-End Cash Collection
detail.abstract: We examine how oil price shocks influence corporate year-end cash collection (YCC) strategies. We distinguish between supply-driven and demand-driven oil shocks and show that firms respond asymmetrically. Supply shocks, which heighten uncertainty and input cost volatility, lead firms to accelerate YCC as a precautionary measure to preserve liquidity. In contrast, demand shocks, which signal economic expansion, prompt firms to reduce YCC by extending credit terms to support growth and strengthen customer relationships. Using a large panel of U.S. public firms from 1987 to 2023, we find these effects are economically significant and more pronounced among financially constrained firms, those operating in low transparency and highly competitive environments, as well as firms with direct oil exposure. Our findings reveal a novel operational channel through which macroeconomic disturbances shape corporate behavior, offering new insights into how firms tactically manage liquidity and financial flexibility in response to external shocks.

AI.tldr: 石油价格冲击对企业年终现金回收策略存在不对称影响：供应冲击促使企业加速回收现金以保持流动性，需求冲击则让企业延长信用期限以支持增长。
AI.research_question: 石油价格冲击如何影响企业年终现金回收策略？供应驱动和需求驱动的石油冲击是否存在不同的影响？
AI.motivation: 理解宏观经济冲击如何通过运营渠道影响企业行为，特别是企业在面对外部不确定性时的流动性管理策略。
AI.theoretical_framework: 基于预防性动机理论和信号理论，区分供应冲击（增加不确定性）和需求冲击（预示经济扩张）对企业现金管理行为的不同影响机制。
AI.method: 使用1987-2023年美国上市公司面板数据，区分供应驱动和需求驱动的石油价格冲击，分析对企业年终现金回收策略的影响。
AI.findings: 供应冲击导致企业加速现金回收作为预防措施，需求冲击促使企业减少现金回收以支持增长；这些效应在财务约束企业、低透明度环境、高竞争行业和直接石油暴露企业中更为显著。
AI.theory_contributions: 揭示了宏观经济冲击通过运营渠道影响企业行为的新机制，拓展了企业流动性管理和外部冲击应对的理论框架。
AI.practical_contributions: 为企业管理者提供了在面对不同类型石油价格冲击时的现金管理策略指导，帮助企业在不确定性中保持财务灵活性。

title: Poverty Identity and Environmental Moral Disengagement : Lab-in-Field Experiments in D.R.Congo
affiliations: Université Libre des Pays des Grands Lacs

detail.title: Poverty Identity and Environmental Moral Disengagement : Lab-in-Field Experiments in D.R.Congo
detail.abstract: This study investigates the causal impact of poverty identity salience on environmental moral disengagement. While a significant body of research explores the structural determinants of environmental behavior, the psychological mechanisms, particularly those linked to social identity, remain less understood. This research addresses this gap by examining whether activating a poverty identity influences how individuals attribute environmental responsibility. We conducted lab-in-Field experiments in Goma, Democratic Republic of Congo, with 138 participants randomly assigned to either a poverty identity priming condition or a neutral control group. Following the priming task, we measured environmental moral disengagement using a newly developed scale. Our exploratory factor analysis identified two primary dimensions of disengagement: (1) externalizing blame ("Not my fault") and (2) anthropocentric prioritization ("Human First (only)"). The results show that priming poverty identity had a large and statistically significant positive effect on the "Not my fault" dimension (β = 3.747, p < 0.01), indicating that participants were more likely to attribute responsibility for environmental problems to external actors like governments and wealthy nations. This effect was particularly pronounced among younger participants. Conversely, the treatment had a small, negative, and marginally significant effect on the "Human First (only)" dimension (β =-0.256, p < 0.1). These findings suggest that activating a poverty identity can causally increase specific forms of environmental moral disengagement, highlighting an important psychological barrier that may prevent pro-environmental action in disadvantaged populations. The study underscores the need for environmental campaigns and policies to consider the influence of identity-related cognitive frames.

AI.tldr: 本研究通过实验发现，激活贫困身份认同会显著增加环境道德推脱，特别是"不是我的错"维度的外部归因，但对"人类优先"维度影响较小，揭示了身份认同对环保行为的心理障碍作用。
AI.research_question: 贫困身份认同的显著性是否会影响环境道德推脱？
AI.motivation: 现有研究主要关注环境行为的结构性决定因素，但对社会身份认同相关的心理机制了解不足，需要填补这一研究空白。
AI.theoretical_framework: 社会身份理论、环境道德推脱理论、身份显著性理论
AI.method: 在刚果民主共和国戈马市进行的实地实验室实验，138名参与者随机分配到贫困身份启动组或中性对照组，使用新开发的环境道德推脱量表测量。
AI.findings: 贫困身份启动对"不是我的错"维度有显著正向影响(β=3.747,p<0.01)，参与者更倾向于将环境问题责任归咎于政府和富裕国家；对"人类优先"维度有微弱负向影响(β=-0.256,p<0.1)；年轻参与者效应更明显。
AI.theory_contributions: 揭示了身份认同作为环境道德推脱的心理机制，拓展了社会身份理论在环境行为领域的应用。
AI.practical_contributions: 为环境运动和政策制定提供了重要启示，需要考虑身份相关认知框架的影响，特别是在弱势群体中设计更有效的环保干预措施。

title: Macroeconomic, Policy, and Global Financial Stress Determinants of Bank Stability: Evidence from the Top 5 Banks in 15 Developing and Emerging Economies (2010-2024

detail.title: Macroeconomic, Policy, and Global Financial Stress Determinants of Bank Stability: Evidence from the Top 5 Banks in 15 Developing and Emerging Economies (2010-2024

declarations.ethicsApproval: This study did not involve human participants, animals, or personal identifiable data; therefore, ethics approval was not required. All secondary data used were obtained from publicly available and credible sources, including official bank reports, World Bank databases, IMF statistics, and other recognized financial data repositories.
declarations.funderStatement: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

detail.abstract: This study looks at how big economic trends, government rules, and worldwide financial problems affect the stability of major banks in poorer and growing countries. The research uses data from the top five banks in 15 countries from 2010 to 2024. It combines information about how well each bank is doing with data about the country's overall economy and global financial stress. The study uses special statistical methods like fixed effects and random effects models, along with checks to make sure the results are reliable. One important part of the study is the Global Financial Stress Index (GFSI), which is made by looking at several stress markers like how much countries owe, how unstable markets are, and how much it costs to get money. The GFSI helps show how financial stress spreads around the world. The study expects to find that good economic growth, keeping inflation under control, and careful money policies help banks stay strong. But having too much debt, sudden changes in policies, and high global stress levels can make banks less stable. This research connects how individual banks perform with the bigger picture of financial stability and global conditions. It offers real data and useful ideas for people who make financial rules and decisions. The results aim to help those in charge of banks and financial policies understand what keeps or harms financial stability, especially in countries that are more at risk in the global financial system.

AI.motivation: 理解在全球金融系统中更易受到击的发展中国家的银行稳定性因素，为政策制定者提供实证基础。

title: Evaluating Technology Integration in Teaching and Learning: A Survey of Public Senior Secondary Schools in Rivers State, Nigeria
affiliations: University of Portsmouth and Ignatius Ajuru University of Education

detail.title: Evaluating Technology Integration in Teaching and Learning: A Survey of Public Senior Secondary Schools in Rivers State, Nigeria
detail.abstract: This study evaluated the extent of technology integration in teaching and learning in public senior secondary schools in Rivers State, Nigeria. A descriptive survey research design was employed, and data were collected through a structured questionnaire. The study population consisted of 6,557 teachers across 302 public senior secondary schools in the state. A sample of 700 respondents comprising 60 principals and 640 teachers was selected using simple and stratified random sampling techniques. The reliability of the instrument was established using the Pearson Product Moment Correlation (PPMC), while face and content validity were confirmed by experts in Educational Management and Educational Technology. Data were analyzed using mean and standard deviation. Findings revealed that while some ICT tools were available in the schools, their integration into classroom teaching was generally low, with over 80 percent of the mean usage scores falling below the criterion mean of 2.5 on a 5-point scale. Although teachers demonstrated moderate to high ICT proficiency, they lacked the institutional support, regular training opportunities, and enabling infrastructure necessary for consistent application in pedagogical practice. Key challenges identified included erratic power supply, poor internet connectivity, limited availability of ICT tools, and the absence of technical support personnel. Based on these findings, the study recommended that the government intensify the implementation of the National ICT-in-Education Policy by equipping schools with adequate infrastructure, ensuring ongoing teacher professional development, and providing dedicated technical support systems. These measures are essential for fostering sustainable and effective technology integration in public senior secondary schools across Rivers State.

AI.tldr: 本研究评估了尼日利亚河流州公立高中技术整合程度，发现虽然部分ICT工具可用，但实际课堂整合水平较低（80%使用得分低于2.5/5分），主要障碍包括电力供应不稳定、网络连接差、设备不足和技术支持缺乏。
AI.research_question: 河流州公立高中教学中技术整合的程度如何？存在哪些主要挑战？
AI.motivation: 评估国家ICT教育政策在公立高中的实施效果，识别技术整合障碍以提出改进建议。
AI.theoretical_framework: 基于教育技术整合理论和教师专业发展理论，关注基础设施、教师能力和制度支持对技术整合的影响。
AI.method: 描述性调查研究设计，使用结构化问卷，从302所学校6557名教师中抽样700人（60名校长+640名教师），采用Pearson相关分析信度，均值和标准差分析数据。
AI.findings: ICT工具可用但课堂整合率低（80%使用得分<2.5/5），教师ICT能力中等偏上但缺乏制度支持、定期培训和基础设施，主要挑战：电力不稳定、网络差、设备有限、无技术支持人员。
AI.theory_contributions: 验证了教育技术整合的多因素影响模型，强调基础设施和制度支持对教师技术应用的关键作用。
AI.practical_contributions: 为政府提供具体政策建议：加强基础设施配备、确保教师持续专业发展、建立专业技术支持系统，以促进可持续有效的技术整合。

title: When Diversity Rules
affiliations: University of North Carolina (UNC) at Chapel Hill - Finance Area, University of Rochester - Simon Business School, University of North Carolina (UNC) at Chapel Hill - Kenan-Flagler Business School and Columbia University

detail.title: When Diversity Rules
detail.abstract: Can gender diversity influence regulatory outcomes? We explore this question in the context of U.S. federal rulemaking, leveraging a novel dataset that tracks 15,000 rulemakers responsible for drafting and advancing 38,000 regulatory projects. We find that teams including women deliberate longer and extensively revise their initial drafts, yet are ultimately less likely to see their projects approved by the agency leadership and issued as final rules. To explain these patterns, we develop a simple model of rulemaking in which output gaps arise from four sources: selection (women are assigned lower-quality projects), cost (differences in the cost of exerting effort), incentive (differences in the return to effort), and evaluation (differential treatment by agency leadership). Reduced-form estimates, aided by a machine-learning C-BERT model, reveal that women are assigned to lower-quality projects and face harsher evaluations, but receive stronger incentives tied to project completion. Structural estimates confirm that disadvantages in selection, cost, and evaluation each contribute meaningfully to the observed gender gap, partially offset by females receiving stronger incentives. Our findings shed light on how female representation shapes regulatory performance and contribute to the broader debate over whether diversity enhances or hinders the effectiveness of public institutions.

title: The Add-to-Cart Revolution in Biologics Development: From Laboratory Modeling to Digital Ordering

detail.abstract: The biologics development industry faces a fundamental disconnect between advances in technological capabilities and persistent operational inefficiencies, characterized by extended timelines, low success rates, and substantial cost barriers. This review examines the potential for an "add-to-cart" model that could transform biologics development from custom, institution-specific processes to standardized, accessible approaches, which is analogous to e-commerce. The add-to-cart model was proposed as a paradigm that enables researchers to specify therapeutic requirements through standardized interfaces and access pre-optimized biological candidates from integrated databases or platforms. This model could potentially improve utility, accessibility, cost-effectiveness, speed, exploration capabilities, and applicability compared to traditional methods. This paper reports areas and inefficiencies in the current development landscapes that could be addressed, while historical precedents from plasmid registries, semiconductor manufacturing, software development, and automotive industries illustrate transformation patterns that could inform this add-to-cart future of biologics development. Key enablers include large-scale biological databases, AI-powered design engines, automated synthesis platforms, standardized interfaces, and appropriate regulatory frameworks. Implementation could fundamentally alter biologics development from bench to bedside, democratizing therapeutic innovation while maintaining scientific rigor. The convergence of computational capabilities, biological databases, and infrastructure development creates conditions for the emergence of the model. Collectively, systematic approaches to biologics development may represent an inevitable evolution toward an add-to-cart approach, providing more efficient and accessible therapeutic innovation.

AI.findings: "加入购物车"模型可通过标准化接口、预优化生物候选库、AI设计引擎等关键推动因素，显著提高效用性、可访问性、成本效益、速度和探索能力。

title: Real-Time Credit Line Management at Scale: An Explainable Architecture for Regulated Banking
affiliations: FICO

detail.title: Real-Time Credit Line Management at Scale: An Explainable Architecture for Regulated Banking
detail.abstract: This paper presents an end-to-end, explainable architecture for real-time Credit Line Management (CLM) deployed at scale in regulated U.S. banking environments. The blueprint combines governed landing‑zone controls, composable decisioning services, and model‑risk‑ready monitoring to reduce exposure and cycle time while preserving auditability and fairness. Field deployments processed ~7–8 million accounts daily, reduced cycle time from ~45–50 days to ~7– 10 days, and avoided approximately $60 million of exposure within three months. We describe technical and operating-model patterns, regulatory alignment, and outcomes from two top‑six U.S. bank programs launched between Q3 2023 and Q3 2024.

AI.tldr: 这篇论文提出了一种可解释的实时信用额度管理系统，在美国银行业部署后显著缩短处理周期并避免大量风险体验。

title: Intellectual Property Rights as the Bedrock of Innovation in the Pharmaceutical and Biotechnology Sectors: A Comprehensive Analysis
affiliations: National Law University and Judicial Academy Assam

detail.title: Intellectual Property Rights as the Bedrock of Innovation in the Pharmaceutical and Biotechnology Sectors: A Comprehensive Analysis
detail.abstract: This article posits that in the pharmaceutical and biotechnology sectors, Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) transcend their legal function to form the foundational bedrock of the entire business model. These industries are characterized by intensive, high-risk, and extraordinarily expensive Research and Development (R&D) cycles. We argue that IPR, with patents at the forefront, provides the indispensable incentive structure required to justify such massive investments. The analysis explores the central role of patents in granting a temporary monopoly that allows for the recoupment of R&D costs and the funding of future projects. Furthermore, the article examines the crucial supporting roles of other IPR forms, including trademarks for brand integrity and patient safety, trade secrets for protecting proprietary processes, and copyright for safeguarding published research and documentation. Finally, we discuss the broader economic and societal relevance of IPR, highlighting its role in fostering competition, facilitating collaboration, and promoting a virtuous cycle of disclosure and subsequent innovation that ultimately benefits public health.

title: The EU Space Act Proposal and its Impact on the Dutch Space Ecosystem
affiliations: VU University Amsterdam and University of Nebraska College of Law

detail.title: The EU Space Act Proposal and its Impact on the Dutch Space Ecosystem
detail.abstract:
On 25 June 2025, the European Commission proposed the Regulation on the Safety, Resilience and Sustainability of Space Activities in the Union (EU Space Act), with the purpose of creating a single legal framework for space activities across all Member States. Applying to European as well as non-EU operators active in the Union, the proposal seeks to strengthen security, resilience, and environmental responsibility in the European space sector. Its adoption is expected to include intense debates focused on debris mitigation standards, cybersecurity obligations, institutional competences, the defence and national security exclusions, and the choice of legal basis under Article 114 TFEU as opposed to Article 189 TFEU.

This paper represents the first systematic examination of the proposal’s impact on Member States, interpreting its provisions through the lens of the Dutch space ecosystem. The Netherlands, the home of ESA ESTEC and of a vibrant and growing commercial space ecosystem, recently announced the transitioning of the Royal Netherlands Air Force into the Royal Netherlands Air and Space Force, reflecting the uncontested strategic importance of space.

The analysis serves as a case study for evaluating legal and operational implications of the EU Space Act, delivering insights applicable to all Member States, in particular to the national authorities that will be responsible for the implementation, and is also relevant to a broader audience: government representatives, policy advisors, legal practitioners, commercial enterprises and SMEs, research institutions, universities, NGOs, and think tanks. By tracing the potential adjustments required and the strategic considerations involved, the paper aims to support informed decision-making as the proposal advances toward its next legislative milestones.

title: The Uruguay Round of GATT and the Birth of TRIPS & GATS: A Paradigm Shift in Global Trade Governance

detail.title: The Uruguay Round of GATT and the Birth of TRIPS & GATS: A Paradigm Shift in Global Trade Governance
detail.abstract: The Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations (1986-1994) represents a watershed moment in the history of international economic law. It fundamentally transformed the postwar trading system, which had been primarily focused on goods, by creating the World Trade Organization (WTO) and introducing binding rules for services and intellectual property.1 This paper analyzes the genesis and structure of two of the Round's most significant outcomes: the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) and the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS). It argues that these agreements signified a paradigm shift, moving global trade governance from a narrow focus on tariffs and border measures to a broader regulatory framework that addresses the "behind-the-border" policies central to the modern knowledge-and service-based economy. The paper examines the core principles, structure, and strategic implications of TRIPS and GATS, highlighting the political and economic forces that shaped them and their enduring impact on international trade, development, and national sovereignty.

detail.title: Electric Vehicle Adoption: Alternative Policy Incentives and Their Substitutability with Direct Subsidies
detail.abstract: Direct purchase subsidies for Electric Vehicles (EVs) are critical in shaping consumer preferences. However, these subsidies impose a significant fiscal burden on governments, while having limited impact on adoption rates. A key concern among early adopters is the need for adequate infrastructure services, especially charging infrastructure given the range anxiety. This paper analyzes the findings of a comprehensive primary survey that we conducted for this study and examines the impact of alternative incentive policies on consumer preferences for electric vehicles, and evaluates the effects of substituting these incentives for direct purchase subsidies. Our findings suggest that policymakers should prioritize incorporating recurring value-added benefits in addition to direct subsidies. Such incentives would help reduce longterm operational costs and offer a sustainable transition to low-carbon mobility.

detail.title: Learning About Other Depositors through Earnings Calls
detail.abstract: We examine if there are valuable signals about depositor behavior released through banks' earnings calls. We use textual analysis on earnings call transcripts to measure the extent of discussions on deposit-related topics. Based on our metrics, we find that an increase in deposit discussions from earnings calls predicts uninsured deposit outflows but does not predict insured deposit flows. The interpretation is that uninsured depositors are responsive to news about their banks' other depositors. Further analysis indicates that the outflow reaction is stronger for banks with depositor characteristics related to more alertness or responsiveness.

detail.abstract: Global shocks in oil markets are transmitted to the final price of gasoline throughout many channel markets. Investigating and measuring these mechanisms is an important issue. The Brazilian case is analyzed because a large part of the country has a car fleet equipped with flexible engines that can be fueled with alcohol or gasoline-4 out 5 cars have this technology-and there is a wide supply of gasoline and alcohol all over the country to the consumer in the filling station. This work uses GVAR Global VAR methodology extended by impulse indicator saturation techniques to analyze the relationship between fuel prices between alcohol and gasoline. The methodology used in the paper allows us to identify outliers and evaluate how changes in the oil price affect gasoline and alcohol prices in different regions, and their lags and allows gains in terms of forecast accuracy.

detail.title: To What Extent Does Occupational Segregation Explain the Gender Pay Gap in The UK?
detail.abstract: To what extent does occupational segregation explain the gender pay gap in the UK? The gender pay gap is defined as the distinct average gap in earnings between men and women in the labour market, usually represented as the percentage difference between the median or mean hourly wages of male and female employees. The gender pay gap is caused by a complex combination of factors. These include occupational segregation, hours and experience, discrimination and cultural norms around gendered roles. Although the gender pay gap is often used to indicate gender inequality in the active participation in the labour force, it does not reflect wage discrimination only, and the gap also includes wider social and organisational factors that impact women's career progression in wages against men.

detail.title: Are Brazilian Investors in Two New Goals-based Bonds for Retirement and Education Rational, Behavioral or Speculators? Evidence from Live Data (2023-2024)
detail.abstract:
In January 2023, Brazil issued a new instrument, Renda+ (or "Retirement Income Extra"), and in August 2023, issued another, Educa+ ("Education Financing Extra"), to help retail investors better save for retirement security and a child's education, respectively. These bonds were designed with very specific cashflows for the respective goals. They combined accumulation, decumulation, inflation and compounding in a single instrument to overcome the typical financial literacy challenges/behavioral biases faced by average investors globally. These bonds, purchased voluntarily, on a simple two-question app, have been successful and are being considered by other countries in the developed and developing world as they address key social challenges. The only two questions to be answered are: (a) start date of targeted cashflows (e.g., one's retirement date or when a child would enter college); and (b) target real amount desired (e.g., R$ 5,000 per month) from such investments, with the idea being that ALL investors, of all levels of financial literacy and income levels can answer such questions. These instruments were issued with various start dates of payments to cater to different age cohorts to target their respective goal-cash flow needs.

Brazil’s Tesouro Nacional (NT) has kept very detailed records of the age of investors in the respective instruments and distributional data (along with gender, region of purchase etc.). One of the intriguing elements from an analysis of the data is that there is a mismatch between what specific instrument the app on NT’s website would recommend to investors based on their target retirement date or child’s date of college entrance (call it “guided choice” or “nudge”), and the actual age/date distribution of investors based on data over the last 1.5-2 years. The unanswered research questions we are pursuing is whether the app is not entirely effective in educating/guiding/nudging investors, or whether investors are displaying rational behavior, exhibiting some form of behavioral bias, or are purely speculating (given that these are very long-duration bonds and hence offer oversized returns if say the investor goes long duration of 50 years and interest rates drop 1% in a short span of time), or some combination of the above. There are six puzzles that we examine within this data set, including why young people are buying bonds targeted to older investors? why older investors appear to be more risk averse and select bonds that are the guided choice? why we get unusual distributions by age in the education bond etc.? We examine the data for all start dates of each of Renda+ (8 instruments with start dates of 2030, 2035….2065) and Educa+ (17 instruments with start dates of 2025, 2026,….2041), and try to discern if the portfolio choices reflect “rational”, “behavioral” or “speculative” decisions.

title: On The 1974 Transition of Greece to Democracy: A Non-Conventional Assessment
affiliations: Athens University of Economics and Business - Department of Economics

detail.title: On The 1974 Transition of Greece to Democracy: A Non-Conventional Assessment
detail.abstract: Since transitioning to democracy in 1974, Greece has enjoyed political stability. However, this stability has been accompanied by a significant slowdown in economic growth. Specifically, the average annual growth rate from 1974 to 2022 has dropped to approximately 1%, down from around 7% in the preceding 20 years. Existing literature suggests we would expect economic growth to accelerate, particularly in the years following Greece's integration into the European Union in 1981. It did not occur, raising the question: why not? This essay offers the explanation that political stability in Greece has resulted from a redistribution mechanism of income and wealth, which was embedded in the 1975 Constitution. This mechanism established a broad range of new 'social' rights while further constraining property rights. By addressing these social rights through the public budget and imposing ad hoc burdens on the private economy, this mechanism enhanced political stability. However, in an open market economy like Greece's, this approach has proven counterproductive, leading to stagnation of economic growth and increasing the likelihood that political stability could be disrupted. To safeguard against the risks to democracy and even national sovereignty that this outlook presents, it is crucial to eliminate the aforementioned redistribution mechanism from the constitution. An even better solution would be to adopt the new constitution recently proposed by six eminent Greeks.

detail.title: The Nexus Between Government Public Debt, Inflation And Per Capita Income in Nigeria: A Generalized Linear Model

declarations.funderStatement: Funded by the Authors

detail.abstract: This study examines the effects of government public debt and inflation on per capita income in Nigeria, covering the period 1981 to 2023. The study utilizes the variables of government public debt, inflation, per capita, money supply and interest rate. The study deploys the generalized linear model based on the heteroscedasticity problem that is associated with the study data set. The study is designed to seek practical implications for economic policies. In addition to examining the impacts of government public debt and inflation on per capita income, the study specifically examines the moderating effect of government public debt and inflation on per capita income as well as investigates the impact of money supply and interest rate on inflation and per capita income. The findings reveal that government public debt has a negative and significant effect on per capita income. In addition, the impact of inflation on per capita income is mild, positive and not significant. Also, the moderating effect of government public debt and inflation is negative and not significant on per capita income. In contrast, the impact of government public debt on inflation is positive and significant. The study recommends a reduction in government fiscal deficit and government borrowing to reduce inflation. The study also recommends fiscal consolidation and the efficient application and management of borrowed funds.

title: Climate Change as a Threat Multiplier: Assessing Its Impact on Resource Scarcity, Migration, And Political Instability
affiliations: University of the National Education Commission, Krakow

detail.title: Climate Change as a Threat Multiplier: Assessing Its Impact on Resource Scarcity, Migration, And Political Instability
detail.abstract: This article examines the conceptualization and application of climate change as a "threat multiplier" in global security discourse. Originating within the U.S. national security community, the term describes how the physical impacts of climate change interact with and exacerbate pre-existing social, economic, and political vulnerabilities, thereby multiplying threats to peace and stability. While the framework has been instrumental in placing climate change on the security agenda, it is also critiqued for potentially constraining policy responses to a reactive, management-oriented posture rather than promoting transformative change. This study employs a qualitative, comparative case study methodology to deconstruct the threat multiplier effect through its cascading impacts. It first analyzes the first-order impact of climate change on critical resources, with a focus on water stress in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) and food insecurity in Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia. It then investigates the secondorder human consequence of climate-induced migration, examining patterns in the Sahel, Bangladesh, and Central America, and highlighting the profound legal and geopolitical challenges posed by the lack of international protection for "climate refugees." Finally, through in-depth case studies of Syria and Sudan, the article analyzes how these combined pressures can culminate in the third-order outcome of political instability and violent conflict. The analysis reveals that governance is the critical mediating variable determining whether climate stress leads to instability. The article concludes by assessing the policy responses of the United Nations, European Union, and the United States, identifying key gaps, and advocating for an integrated policy framework that merges climate adaptation, development, and peacebuilding to address the multifaceted nature of climate-related security risks.

detail.title: The Ambedkar Development Index: Tracking Human Development for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in India (1947–2023)
detail.abstract: This paper presents the Ambedkar Development Index (ADI)-a Human Development Index variant calculated exclusively for India's Scheduled Castes (SC) and Scheduled Tribes (ST). The ADI measures progress in health, education, and income within these historically marginalized groups over seven decades. Drawing on datasets from NSSO, IHDS, NFHS, Census of India, and UNDP, the study compares ADI trends with national HDI benchmarks, highlights regional and gender disparities, and assesses the policy impacts driving change. While SC/ST development has improved substantially since independence, persistent gaps relative to the general population confirm the need for continued targeted interventions.

detail.abstract: Despite geographical distance and economic asymmetry, Nigeria and The Bahamas are strategically positioned to establish a South-South trade corridor that seizes the emerging patterns of global trade. With the traditional trade dependencies being upset, this paper explores how Nigeria's raw material advantage can be combined with The Bahamas' logistics, tourism, and services economy to generate new bilateral economic value. Drawing from trade gap analysis, mapping of transport infrastructure, and institutional congruence, the paper proposes a pragmatic strategy to bridge Africa and the Caribbean by forging robust, diversified supply chains. It also highlights shared legal frameworks, linguistic compatibility, and climate-based economic interests that can ease easy creation of partnerships. Major recommendations span public policy, private sector strategy, and cross-regional diplomacy and form a compelling case for Abuja-Nassau bold and collective action. The paper concludes that trade between Nigeria and the Bahamas is not just desirable-it is needed, long overdue, and potentially transformative.

detail.title: The Economic and Strategic Benefits of Exclusive Economic Zones in Pacific Island States
detail.abstract: The Pacific Island States, though often characterized by limited landmass and small economies, command vast maritime spaces through their Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZs). These zones, legally established under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), grant sovereign rights over marine resources up to 200 nautical miles from a nation's coast. For Pacific nations, this translates into enormous geopolitical and economic significance. EEZs provide access to abundant fisheries, potential seabed minerals, and maritime tourism opportunities, forming the backbone of what is increasingly referred to as the "Blue Economy." Beyond economic dimensions, these maritime zones offer strategic leverage in regional diplomacy, security partnerships, and ocean governance. This article explores how EEZs have evolved into critical assets for the Pacific Islands, enabling them to assert international presence, generate state revenue, and safeguard ecological sovereignty. Through policy analysis and comparative case studies, it reveals the dual function of EEZs as both economic lifelines and strategic tools. The study also highlights key challenges such as illegal fishing, capacity deficits in marine surveillance, and overreliance on foreign actors. Ultimately, it argues that the full realization of EEZ benefits depends on integrated governance, regional cooperation, and sustainable resource management practices tailored to small island contexts.

title: Demographic Expansion in Chad: Reasons and Consequences
affiliations: Independent and National University Singapore

detail.title: Demographic Expansion in Chad: Reasons and Consequences
detail.abstract: Chad, a landlocked nation in Central Africa, is experiencing one of the fastest population growth rates globally, with profound implications for its socioeconomic trajectory, environmental sustainability, and political stability. This article examines the multifaceted drivers and far-reaching consequences of demographic expansion in Chad, employing a multidisciplinary approach that integrates demographic statistics, socioeconomic indicators, and policy analysis. The study identifies high fertility ratesaveraging 6.3 births per woman-as the principal driver of population growth, rooted in a complex interplay of cultural norms, limited access to reproductive health services, and low levels of female education. Contributing factors include a predominantly rural economy reliant on subsistence agriculture, where large family size is traditionally valued for labor, and persistent gender inequality that restricts women's autonomy in reproductive decision-making. The demographic momentum is further sustained by declining mortality rates, attributable to modest improvements in healthcare access and reductions in infant and child mortality, despite ongoing challenges in disease control and nutrition. The consequences of this rapid demographic expansion are wide-ranging. Economically, population growth places severe strain on limited public resources, exacerbating unemployment, underemployment, and income inequality. Education and healthcare systems struggle to keep pace with rising demand, resulting in overcrowded classrooms, insufficient teaching personnel, and inadequate medical infrastructure. Environmentally, the expansion accelerates land degradation, deforestation, and water scarcity, intensifying competition over natural resources and contributing to rural-urban migration. Socially and politically, rapid population growth amplifies pressures on governance structures, fuels intercommunal tensions-particularly over land and water-and complicates efforts toward national stability in a context already marked by fragility and conflict. The analysis underscores the urgent need for integrated policy interventions aimed at moderating population growth while maximizing the potential demographic dividend. Recommended strategies include expanding access to family planning and reproductive health services, investing in female education, promoting economic diversification beyond subsistence agriculture, and implementing sustainable resource management practices. The study concludes that without decisive and coordinated action, Chad's demographic trajectory risks deepening existing socioeconomic and environmental vulnerabilities, undermining prospects for long-term development and stability. Conversely, strategic investment in human capital and resource governance could enable the country to transform demographic pressures into a driver of inclusive growth.

detail.title: A Theory of Wage Rigidity and Unemployment Fluctuations with On-the-Job Search
detail.abstract: I develop a new theory of wage rigidity and unemployment fluctuations. The starting point of my analysis is a generalized version of Burdett and Mortensen's (1998) job ladder model featuring risk-neutral firms, risk-averse workers, and aggregate risk. Because of on-the-job search, my model generates wage rigidity both for incumbent workers, through standard insurance motives, and for new hires, through novel strategic complementarities in wage setting between firms. In contrast to the conventional wisdom in the macro literature, the introduction of on-the-job search implies that: (i) the wage rigidity of incumbent workers, rather than new hires, is the critical determinant of unemployment fluctuations; (ii) fairness considerations in wage setting dampen, rather than amplify, unemployment fluctuations; and (iii) new hire wages are too flexible, rather than too rigid, in the decentralized equilibrium. Quantitatively, the wage rigidity of incumbent workers caused by the insurance motive alone accounts for about one fifth of the unemployment fluctuations observed in the data.

detail.abstract: Private settlements have been consistently encouraged by the Singapore civil justice system. Depending on the context, the settlement may take on many forms, including consent orders and settlement agreements. This begs the question of whether the exact form of settlement matters, or whether a settlement "by any other name" suffices. This article proposes the concept of "sustainable settlements"-comprising the measures of ease of enforcement, finality, and confidentiality-to holistically appraise the effectiveness of settlement mechanisms. The assessment of six settlement mechanisms using these measures clearly indicates that not every mechanism is equally sustainable. Exploring settlement amidst the increasingly complex dispute resolution landscape thus requires greater prudence in the choice of settlement mechanisms, that is informed by both the context as well as jurisprudence concerning enforceability, finality and confidentiality.

detail.title: Assessing Gender Inclusion in Corporate Leadership: A Case of FTSE 350 Companies
detail.abstract:
Background: Despite global efforts to promote gender equality, women remain underrepresented in senior corporate leadership roles, particularly in FTSE 350 companies. Persistent barriers—including unconscious bias, gendered evaluation criteria, and unequal caregiving burdens—continue to hinder women’s advancement, even as research demonstrates the financial and organizational benefits of gender-diverse leadership.

Aim: This study evaluates the extent, drivers, and outcomes of gender inclusion in leadership roles within FTSE 350 companies, focusing on representation, pay equity, and policy effectiveness.

Objectives: The study (1) examines gender representation in employment, management, and executive boards, and (2) assesses pay disparities between genders across FTSE 350 firms.

Methodology: A positivist, deductive approach was employed, analyzing longitudinal secondary data (2013–2022) from Refinitiv Eikon. Descriptive statistics and panel-data regression models tested three hypotheses on gender distribution, leadership representation, and pay gaps. Ethical safeguards ensured data integrity and reproducibility.

Findings: Women constituted only 34.42% of employees and 24.26% of managers, with even lower representation on boards (21.55%). The mean gender pay gap was 71.56%, reflecting systemic inequities. Regression analysis revealed no significant relationship between women’s managerial representation and board diversity (*p* = 0.064), suggesting deeper structural barriers beyond pipeline issues.

Conclusion: While incremental progress exists, FTSE 350 companies must adopt targeted interventions—such as enforced quotas, bias training, and flexible work policies—to dismantle the glass ceiling. The study underscores the need for accountability mechanisms to translate diversity commitments into tangible outcomes, aligning ethical imperatives with organizational performance.

detail.abstract: India's digital banking revolution has transformed the way financial services are accessed and delivered, with platforms like the Unified Payments Interface (UPI), Aadhaar-enabled services, and mobile banking bridging many historical gaps in inclusion. Yet, rural adoption remains inconsistent due to infrastructural constraints, socioeconomic barriers, and trust deficits. This study examines digital banking penetration in Bhende BK, a village in Ahmednagar district, Maharashtra, combining primary survey data from 100 residents with secondary data from RBI, NABARD, and the World Bank. Applying the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) and Diffusion of Innovation Theory, the findings reveal high UPI adoption among youth (78%) but markedly lower uptake among older adults (23%). Major barriers include poor internet connectivity (62%), fear of fraud (48%), limited financial literacy (41%), and language barriers (35%). Comparative insights from Kenya's M-Pesa and Bangladesh's bKash highlight the importance of trust networks, vernacular interfaces, and integration with local financial ecosystems. The study contributes actionable policy recommendations for bridging the rural digital divide, including infrastructure upgrades, localized language support, and targeted literacy programs.

detail.abstract:
In early August, President Donald Trump activated and deployed the D.C. National Guard to the streets of Washington, D.C., purportedly to crack down on the city’s crime. Now, three Republican governors have announced their intention to also deploy Guard troops to the nation’s capital, a predominantly Democratic city. Although there are still more questions than answers concerning the scope, mission, and length of each National Guard unit’s deployment (as well as their coordination with other federal law enforcement agencies), I want to flag a few important questions and provide context for what we know so far. The answers to these questions go beyond the current situation in D.C., as the president’s reliance on untested legal authorities combined with his willingness to use the military for myriad domestic missions in D.C. and elsewhere may well foreshadow broader use of the military in other American cities.These questions include:

- What can the National Guard units do while in D.C.?

detail.abstract: This study examines a performance evaluation process that integrates multiple raters and calibration committees-practices increasingly adopted by organizations yet underexplored in academic research. Using proprietary data, we investigate how supervisors aggregate multi-rater assessments into initial performance ratings and how calibration committees adjust these aggregation decisions. Our findings indicate that both supervisors and calibration committees generally follow the principles of information economics. When aggregating multi-rater assessments, supervisors assess the informativeness of different assessments and place more weight on more informative assessments. However, our results also reveal limitations in information processing. Under conditions of high information load, supervisors appear to rely on cognitive shortcuts, engaging less in detailed weighting decisions based on the informativeness of individual multi-rater assessments. Regarding calibration, we find that committees are less likely to adjust supervisors' aggregation decisions when those decisions are consistent with more informative multi-rater assessments and when supervisors provide well-substantiated justifications, highlighting the complementary roles of multi-rater systems and calibration. Additionally, calibration committees appear to strategically focus on cases where supervisors face a high information load and information sources that may not have been fully incorporated into the initial performance ratings.

detail.title: The Social Cost of Corporate Short-Term Incentives
detail.abstract: We examine how corporate short-term financial incentives compromise product quality, leading to socially costly product failures. Employing a regression discontinuity design around analyst earnings-per-share forecasts, we find that firms conducting share repurchases to narrowly meet earnings targets experience significantly more subsequent product recalls, especially those involving consumer safety issues. These firms also involve in more product-related negative incidents. This relationship is most pronounced among financially constrained firms. These results highlight the real economic consequences of earnings management and provide new evidence on how capital market pressures can create negative externalities for consumers.

title: Dodging Chevron's Redux: The Proper Place for State Farm Arbitrary and Capricious Review

detail.title: Dodging Chevron's Redux: The Proper Place for State Farm Arbitrary and Capricious Review
detail.abstract:
Loper Bright instructed courts to rework how they review challenges to agency decision making and no longer defer to agency construction of statutes. But one critical question remains—how and when courts should engage in a different type of review: the deferential “arbitrary and capricious” standard. In applying this standard post-Loper Bright, courts face a dual risk. First, they may be too hard on government agencies and end up substituting the policy judgments of the court for those of agency experts; State Farm arbitrariness review should be highly deferential. But second, if they engage in this deferential review too early in the process—merging it together with de novo legal review—they may be committing the sin of Chevron and deferring to agencies on legal questions of statutory construction. To avoid this pitfall, this paper lays out a simple formula for courts, combining a decades-long review of statutory and judicial history with an application of the Supreme Court’s most recent decisions.

This article makes two arguments.  First, leaning on cases from before the enactment of the Administrative Procedure Act to the present, this paper argues that State Farm arbitrariness review should be extremely deferential to agency decision making. So long as the agency’s action is “reasonable and reasonably explained,” then courts have no role in substituting their own judgment for that of the agency’s. Second, the Supreme Court was clear in both Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo and an even-more recent case, Seven County Infrastructure v. Eagle County, that de novo legal review and deferential arbitrariness review are two distinct and different steps. If a court conflates the two steps—and some have—it will smuggle deference into legal review and risk a Chevron redux.

Using hypotheticals and real-life cases, including Loper Bright and its sister case Relentless on remand, this paper establishes a clear path for courts to follow. This paper’s recommendation might seem paradoxical: courts should both go easier on agencies when reviewing discretionary decision making for arbitrariness, while being stricter when analyzing whether an agency is behaving lawfully. But this is consistent with the Supreme Court’s guidance—courts must sharply distinguish these two steps and their differing standards of review.

AI.theory_contributions: 明确了后Chevron时代法院审查的双轨制框架，为行政法审查标准理论提供了清晰的操作指引。
AI.practical_contributions: 为法院提供了具体的操作公式，帮助法官避免将尊重性审查过早引入法律问题，防止变相恢复Chevron原则，同时确保对行政裁量的适当尊重。

detail.title: Unlocking Growth? EU Investment Programmes and Firm Performance
detail.abstract: This study evaluates the effectiveness of EU Cohesion Policy as an investment programme, employing a novel dataset that links firm-level data from Orbis with project-level information from the Kohesio database. It focuses on two key questions: (1) Which firms receive EU funding? (2) How does receiving EU funding affect firm performance? By applying a logit model and a local projection difference-in-differences approach, we provide new insights into the allocation mechanisms of EU Cohesion Policy funds and their firm-level impact. Our findings show that funding tends to be allocated to firms that already perform relatively well, and that firms receiving EU funding experience a persistent productivity increase of approximately 3% after 4 years, with smaller and more financially constrained firms experiencing relatively greater improvements. Moreover, funding targeting “SME investment” tends to enhance firm performance disproportionately more than other categories, whereas projects directed the “green transition” appear comparatively less beneficial.

detail.title: Digital Twins in Financial Skills Development: A Future-Ready EdTech Model
detail.abstract: Digital twin technology is the term used to describe virtual, data-driven replicas of real-world entities or systems that are updated in real time. This paper investigates the emergent role of digital twins in the development of financial skills through education technology (EdTech), with a particular emphasis on risk management and budgeting competencies. We provide a definition of the digital twin concept and examine its significance in the context of personalized education and experiential learning. Practical implementation models that demonstrate how digital twins facilitate realistic budgeting simulations and risk management scenarios are presented in conjunction with a review of theoretical frameworks (e.g., simulation-based learning and learning analytics). We present case studies and pilot programs from a variety of regions, such as academic-industry collaborations, school-based financial literacy simulations, and fintech-driven initiatives, to illustrate the global scope of these applications. The technological infrastructure (including real-time data integration and AI-driven learner analytics) and pedagogical models (including adaptive feedback loops and experiential learning) that are facilitated by digital twins are examined. We also address the implications for key stakeholders, including educators who acquire powerful new tools for engagement and assessment, learners who benefit from immersive and personalized practice environments, financial institutions and EdTech developers who see new opportunities for innovation, and policymakers who encounter both opportunities and challenges in scaling such models. The paper is organized as a formal research exposition, consisting of an introduction to the background literature, a comprehensive discussion, the methodology of analysis, and conclusions. Our objective is to develop a future-ready EdTech model that emphasizes the development of financial acumen through the integration of current research and practice. This work is positioned to contribute to the discourse on EdTech innovations in financial education by optimizing scholarly engagement through the use of tone and structure.

detail.abstract:
Trade negotiators have long sought increased access to US subcentral procurement. Coverage of trade agreements is a quantitative component of that effort; there is also a qualitative component. If market access is to be of any value, it must be meaningful. And meaningful access must entail the availability of remedies for disappointed suppliers such as those mandated by the Agreement on Government Procurement. Until now little effort has been made to assess the utilization of such procedures at the subcentral level. This article fills that gap. It assembles data on bid protest rates for 27 of the 37 signatory states as well as 9 of the 13 non-signatory states. Litigation in both groups is robust. On average, protests in the United States are at least as common at the state level as at the federal level. Apart from the inherent value of such data, one would hope that awareness that protests are common at the state level would foster confidence among foreign suppliers and thus encourage greater participation from abroad.

This article was first published by Thomson Reuters in Public Procurement Law Review at 34 Pub. Proc. L. Rev. 289 (2025) and is reproduced with permission of the publishers.

detail.abstract: Japan is not naturally a peace-loving nation; rather, this disposition is the result of the lessons learned from World War II. As a country that had brutally invaded many East and Southeast Asian nations, Japan had to endure the bitter taste of defeat when, on August 6, 1945, the United States dropped its first atomic bomb on the city of Hiroshima. Three days later, on August 9, the second bomb was dropped on Nagasaki. It is estimated that the death toll in these two cities was about 350,000 people. Since then, both the world and the Japanese people have been horrified to realize the extreme destructive power of nuclear weapons. Although memorial ceremonies for the victims of Hiroshima and Nagasaki are still held every year, this year, exactly eighty years later, a worrying reality is gradually emerging as the general situation has changed radically contradictory: the postwar generation is no longer interested in the memory of the historical past. The political leadership is rigorously preparing for rearmament in response to the potential risk of an imminent military conflict. Why is that?

AI.tldr: 日本和平丽向的性格不是天生的，而是二战教训的结果。然而80年后，战后一代对历史记忆失去兴趣，政府正在积极复军备战。本文探讨了这种反差现象的原因。

detail.title: Introduction to Deepfakes and National Security Risks
detail.abstract:
This research explores the emerging threat of deepfake technology and its implications for national security. The study aims to analyze how deepfakes-AI-generated synthetic media-can be weaponized to undermine political stability, spread disinformation, and disrupt critical security frameworks. Employing a mixed-methods approach, the research combines a review of existing literature, case studies of recent deepfake incidents, and expert interviews with cybersecurity and intelligence professionals. Key findings indicate that deepfakes significantly amplify risks related to misinformation campaigns, electoral interference, and geopolitical tensions. Additionally, the study highlights current challenges in detection technologies and policy responses. The conclusion emphasizes the urgent need for enhanced technological countermeasures, cross-sector collaboration, and proactive policy frameworks to mitigate the national security risks posed by deepfakes.

Advancements in artificial intelligence, particularly deep learning, have enabled the creation of highly realistic synthetic media known as deepfakes. These manipulated videos, audio recordings, and images can convincingly depict people saying or doing things they never actually did. Initially gaining attention in entertainment and social media, deepfakes have increasingly raised concerns in the realm of politics, security, and international relations. As the technology becomes more accessible and sophisticated, deepfakes pose novel threats to the integrity of information, public trust, and ultimately, national security.

detail.title: Hidden Taxation and the Rise of the Shadow Fiscal State

publicationDetails.detailsText: Forthcoming in ASU Corporate and Business law Journal, Vol. 7, Issue 1 (2026)

detail.abstract:
This Article uncovers a new and troubling development in U.S. fiscal governance: the use of executive-imposed tariffs as covert instruments of sovereign debt management and fiscal redistribution. Building on a provocative theory circulating among policymakers, it explores the possibility that President Trump’s second-term tariff strategy aimed not merely at confronting foreign adversaries, but at reshaping external balances, stabilizing bond markets, and reducing reliance on foreign capital inflows. At the same time, the use of hidden, regressive tariffs helped to subsidize and sustain large-scale tax cuts for the ultra-wealthy, shifting the fiscal burden onto ordinary consumers without legislative transparency or consent.

Whether or not this theory fully captures the administration’s intent, the constitutional and institutional dangers it reveals are profound. By repurposing tariffs to achieve fiscal objectives, the executive branch constructs a system of hidden, regressive taxation that bypasses Congress’s exclusive authority under Article I of the U.S. Constitution. This practice severs the constitutional link between taxation and democratic accountability, replacing transparent lawmaking with opaque executive discretion. Tariffs, once instruments of trade policy, become de facto taxes imposed without public debate, statutory clarity, or procedural safeguards.

Beyond domestic concerns, this Article situates the phenomenon within the broader framework of international law. The unilateral imposition of tariffs for debt management purposes strains U.S. compliance with core World Trade Organization obligations, undermining the credibility of the rules-based trading system at a moment of deepening global economic fragmentation.

By tracing the emergence of a "shadow fiscal state" through the executive’s tariff powers, this Article offers a new lens for understanding the erosion of constitutional governance and international economic norms. It concludes by proposing structural reforms, including a dual-track system for tariff actions modeled on administrative law procedures, to restore congressional control over fiscal policy and reinvigorate democratic transparency in taxation.

declarations.funderStatement: The author participated as a staff member in two independent projects whose discussions, academic travel, and scholarly exchanges provided background insights that informed the conceptual development of this dissertation. The projects were: Hitotsubashi University Donation-funded Project “Prosecutorial Ethics and Judicial Ethics” (funded by Hogakukan Co., Ltd.). MEXT Special Expenditure Project “Development of Ethics Education for Highly Specialized Professionals, with a Focus on the Legal Profession,” within which Prof. Michael Pritchard and Prof. Elaine Englehardt of Utah Valley University were invited to Hitotsubashi University as Visiting Professors between 2013 and 2015. The author had the opportunity to receive guidance from both professors during their stay in 2014, which served as an initial impetus for part of this dissertation. These projects were entirely separate from the writing and completion of the dissertation.

detail.abstract:
This dissertation reconstructs the normative architecture of legal ethics in U.S. criminal justice and offers a portable framework that links role morality to common morality and political theory. It models legal ethics as a three-faced structure—professional role, common morality, and political philosophy—so that conflicts among them can be diagnosed rather than obscured. Methodologically, it draws on applied ethics. Substantively, it builds on Michael Pritchard’s Professional Integrity to connect subjective deliberation (virtue, character, conscience) with objective, action-guiding standards for professional conduct, and to foreground “good work” as well as the prevention of misconduct. It also engages David Luban’s Lawyers and Justice—especially his account of “neutral partisanship” as the conjunction of partisanship with moral neutrality within an adversary system—to specify what can and cannot be bracketed by role obligations. The analysis clarifies (i) defense counsel’s neutral partisanship vis-à-vis judicial impartiality; (ii) prosecutorial ethics as a dual mandate in which role-based duties and system-facing duties diverge under adversarial stress; and (iii) judicial ethics that calibrate discipline for legal error without chilling independence. To justify institutional departures from common morality, the study favors a “cumulative-weight” test over “minimum-threshold” algorithms, aligning institutional defenses with reason-giving that is sensitive to moral salience. Case studies (the Lake Pleasant and Alton Logan matters) demonstrate preventive and aspirational payoffs—showing how the framework organizes hard cases, guides role-conflict decisions, and makes professional reasoning intelligible to non-lawyers. Overall, the project integrates Pritchard’s virtue-centered integrity with Luban’s institutional analysis to yield an evaluative vocabulary and decision tools for comparative and pedagogical use in legal ethics.


* This is identical to the version available at https://doi.org/10.15057/83104

detail.abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) into Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), including FPV drones, is transforming Intelligence, Surveillance, Target Acquisition, and Reconnaissance (ISTAR) operations. This working paper explores how AI/ML can be designed to enhance compliance with the Law of Armed Conflict (LOAC) and International Humanitarian Law (IHL) by improving target discrimination, reducing civilian harm, and enabling auditable accountability. Drawing on case studies from Syria, Ukraine, Israel, Canada, and France, the paper examines operational, legal, and ethical implications and outlines an architecture for embedding LOAC/IHL “decision gates” directly into ISTAR UAV systems. While the discussion focuses on India’s strategic and legal context, the framework is relevant for emerging UAV operators seeking to integrate responsible AI into military operations. These systems could incorporate an internal “conscience,” asking questions such as: Is this target lawful under international law? Are we certain? Could civilians be nearby? Is there a less harmful way to achieve the mission?

publicationDetails.detailsText: Public Procurement Law Review, Volume 34, pp. 270-288

detail.abstract:
Article XVIII of the World Trade Organizations revised Agreement on Government Procurement (GPA) requires parties to give foreign suppliers access to independent and impartial fora where they can challenge public procurement decisions. However, many US states and Canadian provinces have domestic review procedures that comply with some, but not all, of Article XVIII s requirements. In addition, some US state and Canadian provincial challenge mechanisms arguably comply with a minimal interpretation of Article XVIIL but not with a more robust, purposive interpretation. In other words, US state and Canadian provincial domestic review procedures help to reveal a host of ambiguities in the text of Article XVIII Some of these ambiguities may have been apparent to the negotiators who drafted the text and may reflect deliberate attempts to accommodate diverse national legal systems. We suspect, however, that some other ambiguities may not have been widely understood at the time the text was adopted. The article proceeds line by line through Article XVIIL identifying ambiguities in the text while providing examples of North American sub-central review systems that embody these ambiguities.

This article was first published by Thomson Reuters in Public Procurement Law Review at 34 Pub. Proc. L. Rev. 270 (2025) and is reproduced with permission of the publishers.

detail.abstract: Nepal's Energy Development Roadmap, 2024 sets an ambitious target of attaining an installed capacity of 28,500 MW by 2035. Strategic human resource development and retention are key to attaining the target. But, declining enrolment in relevant disciplines and academic migration paint a worrisome picture. This research investigates and analyses various aspects of job satisfaction among power plant engineers working in Nepal, such as, workplace safety, salary and benefits, training and development, recognition and acknowledgement, mentorship and guidance, level of work related stress and promotion and growth. The findings suggest varying levels of satisfaction, with certain areas necessitating prompt interventions. The research recommends developing a mentorship culture, improving safety, promoting gender inclusion, reevaluating compensation packages, and investing in trainings and development. Additionally, it also offers insights for the government to introduce minimum wage standards for engineers, improve safety practices, encourage gender diversity and align curriculum to suit industry needs.

detail.abstract: As Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) systems approach deployment across critical domains, the convergence of safety, cultural inclusivity, emergency response, and democratic accountability creates unprecedented governance challenges. We present VECTARA(f), a comprehensive deterministic action governance framework that unifies epistemic modeling, cross-domain emergency coordination, indigenous knowledge integration, and quantum-resistant democratic processes. The system introduces twelve foundational innovations spanning from cultural ethnographic NLP to hybrid quantum-classical voting, achieving 35% latency reduction, 92% confidence in black-box AGI modeling, and sub-15-minute cross-domain emergency coordination while maintaining 0.8+ cultural authenticity across diverse knowledge systems. Through comprehensive evaluation across medical, financial, and transportation emergency scenarios, we demonstrate that integrated governance architectures can simultaneously address seemingly contradictory requirements: rapid emergency response with democratic deliberation, cultural diversity with universal principles, and proprietary systems with transparent accountability. This work establishes foundational intellectual property across the emerging AGI governance market while demonstrating commercial viability for enterprise deployment.

detail.title: Analysing Investor's Herding behavior through CSSD and CSAD approach -A Bibliometric Study
detail.abstract: This bibliometric study investigates the evolution of Cross-Sectional Standard Deviation (CSSD) and Cross-Sectional Absolute Deviation (CSAD) Models. It emphasizes their application in analyzing herding behavior in financial markets. The research has drawn on 64 Scopus-indexed articles published between 2009-2024; the research examined thematic trends, author productivity, and methodological advancements in the study of herding behavior. Advanced bibliometric tools such as Biblioshiny and VOSviewer are applied to explore author collaborations and thematic clusters. The result highlights the impact of technological advancements, global crises like COVID-19, the Russia-Ukraine War, the Israel-Hamas crisis, and the increasing influence of social media on joint investment behavior. Critical gaps, including herding in the unexplored asset class and its inferences in developing economies, are highlighted as probable areas for future research. The findings offer insight for investors, policymakers, and professionals to mitigate the influence of herd behavior on the financial market.

AI.tldr: 本研究通过文献计量分析探讨了CSSD和CSAD模型在金融市场羊群行为研究中的演进，发现技术进步、全球危机和社交媒体对投资行为的影响，并指出了发展中市场和未探索资产类别的研究空白。
AI.research_question: CSSD和CSAD模型在羊群行为研究中的演进趋势、应用现状和未来发展方向是什么？
AI.motivation: 理解金融市场中羊群行为的测量模型发展历程，识别研究热点和空白，为投资者和政策制定者提供决策参考。
AI.theoretical_framework: 基于CSSD（横截面标准差）和CSAD（横截面绝对偏差）模型的理论框架，结合行为金融学中的羊群行为理论。
AI.method: 文献计量分析方法，使用Biblioshiny和VOSviewer工具分析64篇Scopus索引文献（2009-2024年），包括主题趋势、作者生产力和方法进展分析。
AI.findings: 技术进步、全球危机（COVID-19、俄乌战争、以哈危机）和社交媒体显著影响联合投资行为；发展中经济体和未探索资产类别存在研究空白。
AI.theory_contributions: 系统梳理了CSSD/CSAD模型的理论发展脉络，识别了羊群行为研究的关键理论演进和未来理论发展方向。

detail.title: Blockchain in the Agrifood Sector: From Storytelling to Traceability Fact-Checking up to New Economic Models
detail.abstract: This paper aims to demystify a lot of misconceptions still widely circulating today about the alleged properties of blockchain and then illustrate the real opportunities that this technology offers for "food system" and how it must be correctly implemented for it to be truly useful, for producers and consumers, particularly in the agrifood sector. The concepts of blockchain opportunities and incompleteness of agri-food chain projects based on blockchain technology are then explained, setting out the minimum and necessary characteristics required to make the use of this technology useful and effective (Minimum Viable Ecosystem). The process governance levels for the development and maintenance of a blockchain traceability project are then illustrated, focusing on the role and responsibility of each player in the supply chain. Finally, the structure of a blockchain solution is described, focusing on a number of structural and technological solutions by outlining the concepts of consistency checking for the validation of input data with appropriate smart contracts, and of information frameworks for the subsequent scrutiny of data in audit operations and the assignment of levels of reliability. These are essential prerequisites for a collaborative blockchain data management to pursue the objective of actual reliability and transparency of information.

title: Variational Galton Machine: From Point Predictions to a Probabilistic Aggregate
affiliations: The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK) - Department of Systems Engineering & Engineering Management, National University of Singapore (NUS) - NUS Business School and INSEAD - Technology and Operations Management

detail.title: Variational Galton Machine: From Point Predictions to a Probabilistic Aggregate
detail.abstract: Decision-makers (DMs) often rely on agents' judgments to estimate unknown quantities of interest. To evaluate decision criteria such as return-risk tradeoffs, they require probabilistic predictions-not just point estimates. However, many agents are either unwilling or unable to provide full probability distributions. In this article, we introduce a novel method that infers a probabilistic aggregate from agents' one-off point predictions. Specifically, each agent provides two point predictions, namely a direct prediction of the quantity of interest and a peer prediction of the average of the others' direct predictions. Our proposed conversion from point predictions to a probabilistic aggregate is straightforward: It has a closed-form solution, involves no tuning parameters, is efficient under the well-known normally distributed information structure, and outperforms benchmark methods across both synthetic and real-world data.

AI.tldr: 这篇论文提出了一种新的方法，通过经纪人的两个点预测（直接预测和同行预测）来推断概率性聚合预测，解决了经纪人不愿或不能提供完整概率分布的问题。该方法简单高效，在正态分布信息结构下有效，并在合成和实际数据上超过基准方法。
AI.research_question: 如何从经纪人的点预测中推断出概率性聚合预测，以支持决策者进行回报-风险交换等决策判断？
AI.motivation: 决策者需要概率性预测来评估回报-风险交换，但许多经纪人无法或不愿提供完整的概率分布，而只能提供点预测。
AI.theoretical_framework: 基于正态分布信息结构的预测聚合理论，利用经纪人之间的相互预测来推断整体的概率分布。
AI.method: 请每个经纪人提供两个点预测：对关注量的直接预测，以及对其他经纪人直接预测平均值的同行预测。通过闭式解转换为概率性聚合。
AI.findings: 方法简单高效，无需调参，在正态分布信息结构下有效，并在合成和实际数据上超过基准方法的表现。
AI.theory_contributions: 提供了一种从点预测推断概率性聚合的新理论框架，扩展了预测聚合的理论基础。
AI.practical_contributions: 为决策者提供了一种实用的工具，可以在经纪人不提供完整概率分布的情况下，仍能获得概率性预测以支持回报-风险交换等决策。

detail.title: Inflation Factors

publicationDetails.detailsText: FRB of Boston Working Paper No. 25-5

detail.abstract: This paper develops an econometric framework for identifying latent factors that provide real time estimates of supply and demand conditions shaping goods- and services-related price pressures in the U.S. economy. The factors are estimated using category-specific personal consumption expenditures (PCE) data on prices and quantities, using a sign-restricted dynamic factor model that imposes theoretical predictions of the effects of fluctuations in supply and demand on prices and associated quantities through factor loadings. The resulting estimates are used to decompose total PCE inflation into contributions from common factors—goods demand, goods supply, services demand, services supply, and inflation expectations—and category specific idiosyncratic components. Validation exercises demonstrate that the estimated factors provide an informative and coherent narrative of inflation dynamics over time and can be effectively used for forecasting and policy analysis.

AI.tldr: 本文开发了一种计量经济学框架，通过符号限制动态因子模型识别供给和需求因素，对美国PCE通胀进行分解，并用于预测和政策分析。
AI.research_question: 如何识别形成美国经济中商品和服务相关价格压力的潜在供给和需求条件？
AI.motivation: 需要一种能够在实时基础上估计供给和需求条件的经济计量方法，以更好地理解通胀动态并支持政策分析。
AI.theoretical_framework: 动态因子模型理论，符号限制方法，供给需求模型的理论预测
AI.method: 使用类别特定的个人消费支出（PCE）价格和数量数据，采用符号限制动态因子模型进行因子估计
AI.findings: 估计的因子提供了有信息量和一致性的通胀动态叙述，能够将总PCE通胀分解为商品需求、商品供给、服务需求、服务供给、通胀预期和特定类别特征组件
AI.theory_contributions: 开发了一种新的计量经济学框架，能够识别潜在供给和需求因素，对动态因子模型理论做出了扩展
AI.practical_contributions: 提供的因子估计可用于通胀预测和政策分析，为实时政策决策提供支持
